metadata.case_name: Assessee-firm (Nandlal Bhimjibhai, Tarachand Bhimjibhai and Rajnikant Bhimjibhai) v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm constituted under a Deed of Partnership dated March 19, 1950. The partners are three brothers - Nandlal Bhimjibhai, Tarachand Bhimjibhai and Rajnikant Bhimjibhai, each having an equal 1/3rd share in the partnership firm.

Prior to November 1949, the three partners of the assessee-firm in partnership with eight others carried on business in Bombay and other places in the name and style of Rajnikant Vitheldas Co. In that larger firm, each one of the three brothers had an equal two annas share each, the other eight partners having the remaining ten annas share.

The larger partnership of Rajnikant Vitheldas Co. was dissolved on October 31, 1949 and on its dissolution the business of the two branches thereof at Nagpur was allotted to the three brothers, who thereupon as from November 1, 1949 constituted themselves into a new firm, viz., the assessee-firm under the deed of partnership executed on March 19, 1950.

The partnership deed recites that the three brothers have agreed to continue the business of the two branches at Nagpur in partnership on the terms mentioned. Clause on capital: The capital of the partnership shall be Rs. 2,40,000 divided into 15 shares of Rs. 16,000 each. Each partner gets five shares.
Clause 10: After meeting all expenses, interest and other charges, the resulting net profit or loss shall be ascertained and shall be divided amongst all partners.

In case of death or insolvency of any partner, the surviving partners have the right to purchase the shares at valuation in preceding balance sheet. In case of retirement, two months notice, remaining partners purchase shares in proportion to their holding at valuation.

For assessment year 1951-52, partners applied for registration under s.26A, deed produced. ITO granted registration on March 20, 1956. Total income Rs. 87,172, allocated equally Rs. 29,057 each under s.23(6).
For 1952-53, renewal granted on March 28, 1957 on same deed.
For 1953-54, applied for renewal on same deed. ITO opined no clause specifying individual shares as required by s.26A. After notices and hearing, rejected on March 28, 1958.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed.
Second appeal to Appellate Tribunal dismissed.
Tribunal referred question to High Court under s.66(1): Whether on proper construction of deed dated 19-3-1950, firm specifies individual shares for 1953-54 as per s.26A.
Bombay High Court answered negative by judgment dated March 15, 1961, holding renewal rightly refused.
In all applications for registration, three partners shown to share profits equally. In books since Nov 1, 1949, profits apportioned equally among three partners.

legal_issues.text: Whether on a proper construction of the partnership deed dated 19-3-1950, the firm sought to be registered for the assessment year 1953-54, can be said to have been constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners as required by section 26A of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: On a proper construction of the various clauses of the partnership deed dated March 19, 1950 it should have been held that the shares of the three individual persons in the profits and losses were clearly specified, namely, that each partner was allotted an equal one-third share and there was hence specification of the individual shares of the partners within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl. 3 and Cl. 10 of deed; s.26A Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

respondent_arguments.text: There was no clause in the deed specifying the individual shares of each partner as required by s. 26A of the Act.

court_reasoning.text: Under cl. 3 of the partnership deed, capital allotted to each partner is equal, viz., 5 shares of Rs. 16,000 each in total Rs. 2,40,000. Cl. 10 states net profit or loss divided amongst all partners. In applications, partners shown equal shares. Books apportion equally since 1949. Reading deed as whole and context, specification of individual shares exists.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Argument of appellant well-founded. Assessee-firm entitled to registration.

court_reasoning.text: Although application must strictly conform, deed reasonably construed. Cites Kylasa Sarabhaiah: preamble indicating shares suffices; principle applies here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Firm entitled to registration under s.26A.

holdings.text: There was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act and the assessee-firm was entitled to registration for the assessment year in question.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kylasa Sarabhaiah v. Commissioner of Income tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Deed reasonably construed for s.26A conformity; shares indicated suffice even if not explicit in certain clauses.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration of firms requires instrument specifying individual shares; procedure, renewal, reference.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines partnership and default equal sharing of profits/losses.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Application requirements, original deed, certificate, renewal for registration.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, reversed Bombay High Court judgment, held assessee-firm entitled to renewal of registration under s.26A for assessment year 1953-54 as deed specifies individual shares.

key_quotes.text: "Reading the partnership deed as a whole and in the context of the relevant circumstances of the case, we are of the opinion that there was specification of the individual shares of the partners in the profits within the meaning of s. 26A of the Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on construction of deed for registration eligibility.

key_quotes.text: "By securing registration under the Act, the partners of the firm obtain a benefit of lower rates of assessment and no tax is directly charged on the income of the firm."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains benefit of registration and strict compliance need.
